DAVID KAUFMAN TO
BE MARRIED JUNE 21
David Kaufman' 28, has announced his engagement to
Miss Rose Levinson, daughter
of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Levinson of this city. The date
of the wedding has been set
for June 21, and the couple
will leave for Europe on June
23.
Kaufman is treasurer of his
class, chairman of the Varsity
Club, and varsity guard in
both basketball and football.
He is also a member of Omicron Delta Kappa.

Meyers, at the Post-office.

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
The latest ruling of the dean of
Women at Ohio State Uniersity was
greeted by a gnashing of teeth of
the amorous swains among the undergraduates at that institution.
Many regretful sighs were heaved
by the young men recalling blissful
moments passed bidding a tender
i farewell to their loving inamoratas.
'It For sad as it may be, after deep
I meditation the dean has augustly decreed that but five minutes of lingering in the hallway, when boy friends
start to leave, will be allowed coeds
in sorority houses and dormitories.

An unlimited cut system has been
inaugurated at the University of
Idaho. Under the terms of this resolution which was adopted by the
faculty those students having high
grades will be allowed to absent
themselves from classes without receiving questioning glances and consequent admonitions from their professors. The authorities, however,
Wish it to be distinctly understood
that upon any abuse of this privilege
an immediate repeal of the concession will follow.

Wild, devil-may-care undergraduates
Was given a rude jolt the other day
by the results of a questionnaire conducted to discover the opinion of
the students of the University of
Rochester on the rather radical plan
of companionate marriage. At that
institution these sober, sensible
Young gentlemen definitely repudiated the severe, puritanical critics of
modern youth, when by an overwhelming vote of 282 to 88, they announced themselves in opposition to
the theory.

The director of physical education
at the University of Arizona is the
Party responsible for some rather
amusing comments on the physical
features of the modern coed to
Which, as he states, her mentality is
directly responsible. Chubbily-constructed coeds (we imagine he
means rather more than merely
Pleasingly plump), he says, are the
most studious of the fair sex. Her
slender sister is more popular socially and consequently suffers a distraction from her scholastic endeavors.

at Furman University have considered it necessary that they should
adopt some emblem of rank to serve
as a means of distinction from the
lower classes. Consequently it has
been decreed that the privilege to
Wear a derby should be strictly reserved to a member of the class of
'28 and every member of that class
has been urged to supply himself
With this article of attire.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 30, 1928

4

COLORS ON ROADSTER SEEN HERE
ALL FOUR CLASSES REPRESENTED IN
EXTRY! EXTRY! Hopkins'
students come into their own at last.
The publicity by the Y. M. C. A.
and notoriety acquired by our embattled banquets have not gone for
naught. There it stands in all its
glory, the feast of all the covetous
eyes of those bitter hostages of the
United. There it stands—the tribute
to the financial integrity and prosperity of the campus—a bright,
shiny, new Hupmobile Six. Imagine!—a Hopkins undergraduate possessing the cash, nay even the credit,
to buy an automobile.
Truly, our Baltimore auto dealers
are optimists. And more than optimists. See their sense of the fitness of things in the color combination they present. Cream yellow
with green and black trimmings,

and all shiny nickle. For verily,
the creamy smoothness of the Duco
sets off the peaches-and-cream complexion of our seniors. And lo!—
how well the shiny nickle pictures
the coinage in our juniors' treasury.
And black—ah—black as our sophomores' hopes of returning to the
University for the third year.
Freshmen? Yes, you guessed it.
Green stands for our poor, pampered class of '31, as yet untainted
by the demoralizing Art of Fisticuffs. But watch—the crowd has
made room; two of our uniformed
Rot Club men step in; there's the
idea—dispense with uniforms, rifles,
sabers and such. Supply them all
with roadsters, sport model, motherin-law seat and all. Excellent! But
wait. The next war will be fought
in the air.

DAVID KAUFMAN TO
BE MARRIED JUNE 21
David Kaufman' 28, has announced his engagement to
Miss Rose Levinson, daughter
of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Levinson of this city. The date
of the wedding has been set
for June 21, and the couple
will leave for Europe on June
23.
Kaufman is treasurer of his
class, chairman of the Varsity
Club, and varsity guard in
both basketball and football.
He is also a member of Omicron Delta Kappa.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 30, 1928

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
The latest ruling of the dean of
Women at Ohio State Uniersity was
greeted by a gnashing of teeth of
the amorous swains among the undergraduates at that institution.
Many regretful sighs were heaved
by the young men recalling blissful
moments passed bidding a tender
i farewell to their loving inamoratas.
'It For sad as it may be, after deep
I meditation the dean has augustly decreed that but five minutes of lingering in the hallway, when boy friends
start to leave, will be allowed coeds
in sorority houses and dormitories.

An unlimited cut system has been
inaugurated at the University of
Idaho. Under the terms of this resolution which was adopted by the
faculty those students having high
grades will be allowed to absent
themselves from classes without receiving questioning glances and consequent admonitions from their professors. The authorities, however,
Wish it to be distinctly understood
that upon any abuse of this privilege
an immediate repeal of the concession will follow.

H. E. BOSLEY Est.

The popular conception of the
Wild, devil-may-care undergraduates
Was given a rude jolt the other day
by the results of a questionnaire conducted to discover the opinion of
the students of the University of
Rochester on the rather radical plan
of companionate marriage. At that
institution these sober, sensible
Young gentlemen definitely repudiated the severe, puritanical critics of
modern youth, when by an overwhelming vote of 282 to 88, they announced themselves in opposition to
the theory.

The director of physical education
at the University of Arizona is the
Party responsible for some rather
amusing comments on the physical
features of the modern coed to
Which, as he states, her mentality is
directly responsible. Chubbily-constructed coeds (we imagine he
means rather more than merely
Pleasingly plump), he says, are the
most studious of the fair sex. Her
slender sister is more popular socially and consequently suffers a distraction from her scholastic endeavors.
For some reason or other seniors
at Furman University have considered it necessary that they should
adopt some emblem of rank to serve
as a means of distinction from the
lower classes. Consequently it has
been decreed that the privilege to
Wear a derby should be strictly reserved to a member of the class of
'28 and every member of that class
has been urged to supply himself
With this article of attire.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 30, 1928

4

COLORS ON ROADSTER SEEN HERE
ALL FOUR CLASSES REPRESENTED IN
EXTRY! EXTRY! Hopkins'
students come into their own at last.
The publicity by the Y. M. C. A.
and notoriety acquired by our embattled banquets have not gone for
naught. There it stands in all its
glory, the feast of all the covetous
eyes of those bitter hostages of the
United. There it stands—the tribute
to the financial integrity and prosperity of the campus—a bright,
shiny, new Hupmobile Six. Imagine!—a Hopkins undergraduate possessing the cash, nay even the credit,
to buy an automobile.
Truly, our Baltimore auto dealers
are optimists. And more than optimists. See their sense of the fitness of things in the color combination they present. Cream yellow
with green and black trimmings,

and all shiny nickle. For verily,
the creamy smoothness of the Duco
sets off the peaches-and-cream complexion of our seniors. And lo!—
how well the shiny nickle pictures
the coinage in our juniors' treasury.
And black—ah—black as our sophomores' hopes of returning to the
University for the third year.
Freshmen? Yes, you guessed it.
Green stands for our poor, pampered class of '31, as yet untainted
by the demoralizing Art of Fisticuffs. But watch—the crowd has
made room; two of our uniformed
Rot Club men step in; there's the
idea—dispense with uniforms, rifles,
sabers and such. Supply them all
with roadsters, sport model, motherin-law seat and all. Excellent! But
wait. The next war will be fought
in the air.
